A grifter is an old-fashioned term that refers to a person who engages in deceitful or unscrupulous behavior, often with the intention of achieving financial gain or other benefits through manipulation or exploitation.
A grifter, in its original context, refers to a confidence trickster or scam artist who swindles people out of their money by pretending to be someone they're not.
Grifters often use false pretenses, charm, and persuasion to gain the trust of their marks (victims) before exploiting them financially.

In the late 19th and early 20th centuries, grifting was associated with traveling con artists who would move from town to town, selling fake or useless products, or running scams on unsuspecting locals.
Traditionally, grifters operated through in-person interactions, using tactics like fake investment schemes, pyramid scams, or get-rich-quick plans.
In the early 20th century, grifting was associated with street scams, where con artists would pose as salespeople, fortune tellers, or experts to deceive and fleece unsuspecting victims.
Think three-card Monte, shell games, or snake oil peddlers.
